CM Jotason, from Lavaca Bay to El Paso, on the Upper Rio Grande
We are confident that these surveys, when completed, will show, that
tho southern route for a rail-road connecting the Guli of Mexico with
,1,'e Gulf of California, extending from Galveston or Lavaca Bay,
by El Paso is far preferable to the northern route through Missouri.
It is shorter, and the country is so uniform, rising by regular gradations from the gulf on the cast to the summit of tho table-lands of
the Gila, and declining by equally regular gradations to the Pacific
Coast, that the eost of constructing a rail-road on this route will
scarcely amount to two-thirds of the cost on the northern route.
Texas has a deep interest ill connecting herself with the great pub-
lie works of the United States, and she has public domain enough to
build more roads than are in all New-England. A grand trunk road
from Austin, with branches to Houston and Galveston, passing in the
vicinities of Montgomery, Washington, San Augustine, Nacogdoches,
would enter Louisiana in about the same parallel of latitude with
Alexandria, and connect with the proposed road from thence to New-
< lileaiis. In the other direction, her roads should radiate towards
New-Mexico and the valleys of tho Pacific. The committee have
been instructed, particularly and urgently, to invite the co-operation of
Texas.
